name: Purépecha
imgAlt: Distribution of Purépecha in Mexico. Green indicates historical language homeland and red is modern-day speakers.
description: Purépecha was the principal language of the Tarascan state, which was founded in the early 14th century, occupied more or less same area as Michoacán, and fell to the Spanish in 1530. Purépecha is also known as Tarascan as a result.

name: Nahuatl
imgAlt: Current (red) and historical (green) geographic extent of Nahuatl
description:
There are numerous dialects of Nahuatl, some of which are mutually unintelligible. Most Nahuatl speakers also speak Spanish, except for some of the elderly.

Classical Nahuatl was the language of the Aztec empire and was used as a lingua franca in much of Mesoamerica from the 7th century AD until the Spanish conquest in the 16th century.

name: Totonac
imgAlt: Current locations where Totonac is being spoken
description: The Totonac people are an indigenous group native to Totonacapan along the Gulf of Mexico.

name: Chinantec
imgAlt: Current location of people speaking Chinantec
description: As there is only some mutual intelligibity between the different Chinanteco languages, they are considered by most linguists as separate languages rather than dialects.

name: Yucatec Maya
imgAlt: Region where the language used to be spoken
description: a Mayan language spoken in the Yucatán Peninsula, including part of northern Belize. There is also a significant diasporic community of Yucatec Maya speakers in San Francisco, though most Maya Americans are speakers of other Mayan languages from Guatemala and Chiapas.

name: Tzeltal Maya
imgAlt: In green, the location where Tzeltal Mayan was spoken
description: The area in which Tzeltal is spoken can be divided in half by an imaginary north–south line; to the west, near Oxchuc, is the ancestral home of the Tzeltal people, predating Spanish colonials, while the eastern portion was settled primarily in the second half of the twentieth century.

name: Tzotzil Maya
imgAlt: In Pink, the location where Tzotzil Maya was spoken
description: Some speakers may be somewhat bilingual in Spanish, but many are monolingual Tzotzil speakers. In Central Chiapas, some primary schools and a secondary school are taught in Tzotzil.

name: Mixtec
imgAlt: the area where the Mixtec language was spoken back then
description: Mixtec is spoken in Mexico and is closely related to Trique and Cuicatec.

name: Zapotec
imgAlt: Image ith a region of where Zapotec Empire was and where people used to speak the language
description: anguages are a group of around 50 closely related indigenous Mesoamerican languages that constitute a main branch of the Oto-Manguean language family and are spoken by the Zapotec people from the southwestern-central highlands of Mexico.

name: Otomí
imgAlt: Regions where the Otomí language used to be spoken
description: Otomi consists of several closely related languages, many of which are not mutually intelligible.

name: Ch'ol
imgAlt: In light blue, the region where the Ch'ol langague is being spoken
description: The Ch'ol (Chol) language is a member of the western branch of the Mayan language family used by the Ch'ol people in the states of Chiapas, Tabasco, and Campeche in Mexico

name: Mazatec
imgAlt: The region where Mazatec is being spoken today
description: The group is often described as a single language called Mazatec, but because several varieties are not mutually intelligible, they are better described as a group of languages.

name: Huastec
imgAlt: The region where the Huastec language is being spoken today
description: spoken by the Téenek people living in rural areas of San Luis Potosí and northern Veracruz.

name: Mazahua
imgAlt: The region where Mazahua is still being spoken today
description: spoken in the central states of Mexico by the ethnic group that is widely known as the Mazahua but calls itself the Hñatho

name: Tlapanec
imgAlt: The region where Mazahua is still being spoken today
description: Like other Oto-Manguean languages, it is tonal and has complex inflectional morphology.

name: Mixe
imgAlt: the regions where Mixe was spoken
description: languages of the Mixean branch of the Mixe–Zoquean language family indigenous to southern Mexico.

name: Tarahumara
imgAlt: The region where Tarahumara is being spoken today
description: Rarámuri is spoken by 70,000 or more Indigenous Mexicans living in the state of Chihuahua. There is no consensus among specialists on the number of dialects: competing proposals include two (Western and Eastern); four (Western, Northern, Southern, Eastern); and five, according to field surveys conducted in the 1990s by linguists working for the Mexican government

name: Zoque
imgAlt: The region where Zoque was spoken
description: a primary branch of the Mixe–Zoquean language family indigenous to southern Mexico by the Zoque people.

name: Tojolab'al
imgAlt: The region where Tojolab'al is being spoken in today
description: a Mayan language spoken in Chiapas, Mexico by the Tojolabal people. Tojol-ab'al is spoken, principally in the departments of the Chiapanecan Colonia of Las Margaritas, by about 70,000 people. It is related to the Chuj language.

name: Chontal de Tabasco
imgAlt: Region where Chontal de Tabasco was spoken
description: The Chontal spoken in the state of Tabasco is a Mayan language.

name: Huichol
imgAlt: Region where Huichol is being spoken
description: It is spoken by the ethnic group widely known as the Huichol (self-designation Wixaritari), whose mountainous territory extends over portions of the Mexican states of Jalisco, San Luis Potosí, Nayarit, Zacatecas, and Durango, mostly in Jalisco.

name: Amuzgo
imgAlt: Region where Amuzgo is being spoken
description: Like other Oto-Manguean languages, Amuzgo is a tonal language. From syntactical point of view Amuzgo can be considered as an active language.

name: Chatino
imgAlt: Region where Chatino was spoken
description: These languages are a branch of the Zapotecan family within the Oto-Manguean language family.

name: Tepehuano del sur
imgAlt: Region wher Tepehuano del sur is spoken
description: Tepehuán (Tepehuano) is the name of three closely related languages of the Piman branch of the Uto-Aztecan language family, all spoken in northern Mexico. The language is called O'otham by its speakers.

name: Mayo
imgAlt: The region where Mayo is spoken
description: known as Yorem Noki to the Mayo (Yoreme) people, is an Uto-Aztecan language. It is spoken by about 40,000 people, who live in the southern portion of the Mexican state of Sonora and in the north of the neighboring state of Sinaloa.

name: Popoloca
imgAlt: The region where Popoluca is spoeken
description: Popoloca is an indigenous Mexican cluster of languages of the Popolocan branch of the Oto-Manguean language family, closely related to Mazatec.

name: Cora
imgAlt: A map of a cluster of other languages, with Cora also being included in the middle of the cluster
description: It is spoken by the ethnic group that is widely known as the Cora, but who refer to themselves as Naáyarite. The Cora inhabit the northern sierra of the Mexican state Nayarit which is named after its indigenous inhabitants.

name: Trique
imgAlt: A region where Trique is spoken in today
description: a family of Oto-Manguean spoken by 30,000 Trique people of the Mexican states of Oaxaca and the state of Baja California

name: Yaqui
imgAlt: The region where Yaqui is being spoken today
description: primary homelands are in Río Yaqui valley in the northwestern Mexican state of Sonora. Today, there are eight Yaqui Pueblos in Sonora.

name: Huave
imgAlt: Region where Huave is being spoken
description: The language is spoken in four villages on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, in the southeast of the state

name: Popoluca
imgAlt: Region where Popoluca was spoken, its not as well known as Popoloca
description: Sierra Popoluca (poi) and Texistepec Popoluca (poq) are Zoquean; that is, they are more closely related to the Zoque languages of Chiapas, Oaxaca and Tabasco than to the nearby Sayula and Oluta Popoluca languages.

name: Cuicatec
imgAlt: Region where Cuicatec is spoken
description: The Ethnologue lists two major dialects of Cuicatec: Tepeuxila Cuicatec and Teutila Cuicatec.

name: Pame
imgAlt: region where the Pame langagues are still being spoken to today
description: The Pame languages are a group of languages in Mexico that is spoken by around 12,000 Pame people in the state of San Luis Potosí. It belongs to the Oto-Pamean branch of the Oto-Manguean language family.

name: Mam
imgAlt: On number 4 of the map, you will see the Mam language
description: spoken by around half a million people in Guatemala and Mexico.

name: Q'anjob'al
imgAlt: The region of Q'anjob'al is spoken
description: a Mayan language from the Q'anjobalan branch spoken primarily in Guatemala and part of Mexico.

name: Tepehuano del Norte
imgAlt: Region where Tepehuano del Norte is spoken
description: Tepehuán (Tepehuano) is the name of three closely related languages of the Piman branch of the Uto-Aztecan language family, all spoken in northern Mexico. The language is called O'otham by its speakers.

name: Tepehua
imgAlt: region where Tepehua is spoken
description: They speak Tepehua languages, which belong to the Totonacan language family.

name: Chontal de Oaxaca
imgAlt: region where Chontal de Oaxaca is spoken
description: The Chontal spoken in the state of Oaxaca, and usually referred to as Oaxaca Chontal, is a language family that has not been shown to be related to any other

name: Sayultec
imgAlt: Map where multiple sub languages are spoken, with Sayultec being one of the sub languages.
description: is a Mixean language spoken by around 5,000 indigenous people in and around the town of Sayula de Alemán in the southern part of the state of Veracruz, Mexico.

name: Chuj
imgAlt: regions of indigenous languages being spoken in both Guatemala and also Mexico. Chuj is number one of the map.
description: a Mayan language spoken by around 40,000 members of the Chuj people in Guatemala and around 3,000 members in Mexico.

name: Akateko
imgAlt: Region where Akateko is mainly spoken
description: Akatek is a Mayan language spoken by the Akateko people primarily in the Huehuetenango Department, Guatemala in and around the municipalities of Concepción Huista, Nentón, San Miguel Acatán, San Rafael La Independencia and San Sebastián Coatán. A number of speakers also live in Chiapas, Mexico.

name: Chichimeca jonaz
imgAlt: Shared map of both Chichimeca Jonaz and Chichimeca Pame.
description: Chichimeca or Chichimeca Jonaz is an indigenous language of Mexico spoken by around 200 Chichimeca Jonaz people in Misión de Chichimecas near San Luis de la Paz in the state of Guanajuato.

name: Ocuilteco
imgAlt: Region where Ocuilteco is spoken
description: Ocuiltec is spoken primarily in the municipality of Ocuilan in the villages Cinco Caminos, Colonia Doctor Gustavo Baz, El Capulín, El Totoc (San José Totoc), Lomas de Teocaltzingo (Loma de Tecalzingo), Ocuilán de Artéaga, San Juan Atzingo, Santa Lucía, Santa Martha, and Santa María Nativitas. It may have been spoken in the adjacent area of Morelos, though Matlatzinca could have also existed in it.

name: Guarijío
imgAlt: Region where Guarijío is being spoken
description: The Guarijío language group belongs to the Uto-Aztecan family; genetically, Guarijío is very closely related to Tarahumara. Guarijío is spoken in the states of Chihuahua and Sonora.

name: Q'eqchí
imgAlt: Region of Q'eqchí is being spoeken today
description: Q'eqchi ' is a Mayan language and the only K'ichean language spoken in Mexico.

name: Matlatzinca
imgAlt: Region where Matlatzinca is being spoken
description: is an endangered Oto-Manguean language of Western Central Mexico.

name: Pima Bajo
imgAlt: Region where Pima Bajo is being spoken
description: a Mexican indigenous language of the Piman branch of the Uto-Aztecan language family, spoken by around 1,000 speakers in northern Mexico.

name: Ngiba/Ngiwa
imgAlt: The gernal region of where Ngiwa is being spoeken
description: Ngiba (Popoloca) language, its four dialectal variants are included in UNESCO's Atlas of the World's Languages ​​in Danger , and two are listed by INALI (the National Institute of Indigenous Languages) as being at high risk of extinction.

name: Lacandón
imgAlt: Region where Lacandón is being spoken in
description: also known as Jach-t'aan, is considered to be at medium risk of extinction. The language most closely related to Jach-t'aan is Yucatec Maya, or Maayat'aan .

name: Seri
imgAlt: Region where Seri is being spoken
description: There have been attempts to relate Seri to other languages ​​and include it in an established family, but current linguistic evidence shows that Seri does not share characteristics that would place it in any family. Consequently, Seri can be considered a language isolate

name: Kʼicheʼ
imgAlt: Region where Kʼicheʼ is being spoken
description: a Mayan language spoken by the Kʼicheʼ people of the central highlands in Guatemala and Mexico.

name: Kumiai
imgAlt: Region where Kumiai is being spoken
description: The Kumiai language , or Tipai as its speakers call it, belongs to the Cochimí-Yuman language family. Its closest relatives are Lipai and Jamu, both spoken in the United States. Currently, it is a language at very high risk of extinction.

name: Teko
imgAlt: Region where Teko is being spoken today
description: Tektitek (name in Guatemala) or Teko (name in Mexico), called b'a'aj by native speakers, (also known as Tectiteco, Teco, Kʼontiʼl, Qyool, among others) is a Mayan language classified under the Mamean branch, spoken by the Teko people of Chiapas, Mexico and southern Huehuetenango Department, Guatemala.

name: Paipai
imgAlt: Region where Paipai is being spoken
description: Paipai , or Jaspuypai as its speakers call it , is spoken in the state of Baja California, in the municipality of Ensenada. It belongs to the Cochimí-Yuman language family.

name: Tohono O’odham
imgAlt: Region where Tohono O’odham is being spoken
description: a Uto-Aztecan language of southern Arizona and northern Sonora, Mexico, where the Tohono Oʼodham (formerly called the Papago) and Akimel Oʼodham (traditionally called Pima) reside.

name: Ixcatec
imgAlt: Map with a bunch of sub languages in the map, one of the sub languages is Ixcatec
description: The small number of current speakers is the result of a steady decline over the last 60 years, which can be attributed to anti-illiteracy campaigns by the Mexican government that discouraged the use of indigenous languages, migration from the area to the cities, and the small initial population of speakers of the language.

name: Kaqchikel
imgAlt: Region where Kaqchikel is being spoken in
description: Kaqchikel is a Mayan language; its sister language is Tz'utujil (spoken in Guatemala).

name: Cucapá
imgAlt: Region where Cucapá is being spoken
description: The Cucapá or Kuapá language belongs to the Cochimí-Yuman family and has no internal variation. It is spoken in the states of Baja California and Sonora.

name: Popti
imgAlt: Map of all the different languages in Guatemala, having Polti right below Chuj
description: The Jakaltek language, also known as Jakalteko or Poptiʼ, is a Mayan language from the Q’anjob’alan-chujean branch spoken by the Jakaltek people in some municipalities in the state of Chiapas, Mexico and the municipality of Jacaltenango in the department of Huehuetenango, Guatemala in the border between both countries.

name: Ayapaneco
imgAlt: Region where Ayapaneco is being spoken
description: It is spoken in the state of Tabasco and together with the Texistepeceño and the Popoluca of the Sierra make up the Gulf Zoquean branch of the Mixe-Zoquean family.

name: Ixil
imgAlt: region where the Ixil langagues is being spoken
description: Ixil is a Mayan language, genetically very close to Awakateko. It is spoken in the states of Campeche and Quintana Roo

name: Oluteco
imgAlt: Region where Oluteco is being spoken
description: It has no variants and is spoken in the state of Veracruz, in the municipality of Oluta, hence its name.

name: Kiliwa
imgAlt: Region where Kiliwa is being spoken
description: Kiliwa, or Ko'lew, belongs to the Cochimí-Yuman language family and is spoken in eight communities in the municipality of Ensenada, Baja California .

name: Kikapú
imgAlt: Region where Kikapú is being spoken
description: The Kickapoo language is the only representative of the Algic language family found in Mexico.

name: Aguacatec
imgAlt: A map of all the different indigenous languages in Guatemala with Aguacatec being retested in a dark blue dot.
description: Awakatek (also known as Aguateco, Awaketec, Coyotin, and Balamiha, and natively as Qa'yol) is a Mayan language spoken in Guatemala, primarily in Huehuetenango and around Aguacatán. The language only has fewer than 10,000 speakers, and is considered vulnerable by UNESCO. In addition, the language in Mexico is at high risk of endangerment

name: Tlahuica
imgAlt: Region where Tlahuica is being spoken
description: Pjiekakjoo, also known as Tlahuica or Ocuilteco (both exonyms, meaning names given to the language by non-speakers), is a language belonging to the Oto-Manguean family; the closest language to Tlahuica is Matlatzinca. It is spoken in the municipality of Ocuilán in the State of Mexico.

name: Poqomchi
imgAlt: Region where Poqomchi is being spoken
description: Poqomchiʼ is a Quichean-Mamean Mayan language spoken in central Guatamala
